29.author: Similar_Candidate789
29.body:
This wasn’t just in Texas. Pride celebrations actually grew out of a rebellion against laws in New York. The rebellion at stonewall was the first instance of fighting back against the unjust system. Cops used to troll through the park in short shorts and get the men to try to hook up with them and arrest them. They used to *constantly* raid the only gay bar in town (stonewall) for no reason other than gay people gathered there. Gay people fought back. 

If Lawrence v Texas is overturned, we will return to that in states like Texas, Mississippi, Louisiana, and most likely Florida. Homes and bars will be raised constantly for “suspicion of homosexual activity”. Having sex with your partner will be forbidden. It’ll go further though than just “sodomy” - it’ll be a ban on any form of activity, including kissing or holding hands, and any artwork or cinema of the same. Simply watching a gay show like will and grace on tv will have you arrested and probably register as a sex offender. 

It will, quite literally, be the coming of Gilead. There is a reason it’s so terrifying is because that’s how it used to be and republicans don’t just want us to go back there they want to go even further.

29.author: merrickraven

29.author: Similar_Candidate789

This last Pride I watched two documentaries on Hulu about it and I cried like a baby. We’ve come so, so far and they want us to go back. 

I absolutely refuse.

29.author: merrickraven
29.body:
I’m so scared of it going back. I was brave once, but I no longer see myself able to take a baton to the face or chest again. 

Two trans people married to each other. And we live in a deeply red state. Until recently when I thought about it at all, I just was happy that we had won enough that we could enjoy our normal lives. 

And now they are coming again. And all the queer people under 30 look at me like I’m a crazy conspiracy theorist when I tell them how bad it might get if we don’t mobilize.

29.author: Similar_Candidate789
29.body:
We can be happy about progress but scared about it being taken away. Complacency leads to losing our rights. 

Keep warning them. Also know, I think it’s going to get better. Evil never wins. History proves it. We can be on our toes and hope we are wrong.

42.author: dj012eyl
42.body:
> You're quick to dismiss Trump's debt on the basis it resulted in part due to COVID. 

Not really.  Total COVID expenditures are quite large - about 4.6T through the end of 2022 (3 years) as you can see [here](https://www.usaspending.gov/disaster/covid-19?publicLaw=all), so that'd come out to a bit under 2T in the first year, which was the increase that was seen over the 1T projected deficit (3.1T versus ~1T).  The tax breaks he implemented were back in 2017 and, from what I read at least, mostly took effect before 2020.  Correct me if I'm wrong on any of this.

>  And a huge financial crisis hit at the end of W. Bush's term, with massive federal stimulus commitments that mostly hit during Obama's Presidency

Well, yeah, enormous "economic stimulus" without a corresponding change in tax will run up a huge deficit.  As you can see from the chart in the previous message, deficits under Obama continue above Bush levels throughout his presidency.  Just the facts here.

> Also Trump's increase over Obama's 8 years happened in just 4 years.

Yep, I accounted for that in my first message.  8 year adjusted for Trump would be a 56% increase, or roughly 5.7% year over year.
